title: Boxlib particle support

content.raw: I tested this using output from our WarpX code, which uses the standard Boxlib particle file format. I also generated a sample Nyx dataset by running the Lyman alpha test problem from the github repo, and it seemed to work as well. Unfortunately, the sample Nyx datasets on yt's data page seem to be out of date.
content.html: I tested this using output from our WarpX code, which uses the standard Boxlib particle file format. I also generated a sample Nyx dataset by running the Lyman alpha test problem from the github repo, and it seemed to work as well. Unfortunately, the sample Nyx datasets on yt's data page seem to be out of date.

content.raw:
this looks pretty good to me.

Castro also supports particles, which should be in this same format.  I don't have any setups that use them, but @ChrisMalone might
content.html:
this looks pretty good to me.

Castro also supports particles, which should be in this same format. I don't have any setups that use them, but Chris Malone might

content.raw: @friesen might be interested in this too, since he's been doing a lot of Nyx
content.html: Brian Friesen might be interested in this too, since he's been doing a lot of Nyx
Looks great! Thanks Andrew Myers!

content.raw: I unfortunately do not have any Castro data sets with particles.
content.html: I unfortunately do not have any Castro data sets with particles.

content.raw: I generated a Castro dataset with tracer particles by running the hydro_tests/RT_particles test problem, but it actually looks like the file format is pretty different. The particles are stored in a big ASCII file and not sorted onto boxes or anything like that.
content.html: I generated a Castro dataset with tracer particles by running the hydro_tests/RT_particles test problem, but it actually looks like the file format is pretty different. The particles are stored in a big ASCII file and not sorted onto boxes or anything like that.

content.raw: okay, let's fault Castro there.  I'll file an issue with Castro on github that it should switch to the Nyx/WarpX format.
content.html: okay, let's fault Castro there. I'll file an issue with Castro on github that it should switch to the Nyx/WarpX format.

content.raw: Can you add the particle datasets you've created for testing this functionality to yt-project.org/data? It would also be good if you used those datasets for some form of answer testing. I'd also like to see the an update to the docs on loading boxlib data to include some mention of particle support, in addition to the code support table in the reference section.
content.html: Can you add the particle datasets you've created for testing this functionality to yt-project.org/data? It would also be good if you used those datasets for some form of answer testing. I'd also like to see the an update to the docs on loading boxlib data to include some mention of particle support, in addition to the code support table in the reference section.

content.raw: This should be taken care of now.
content.html: This should be taken care of now.

content.raw: not an answer test, please use `requires_file` instead
content.html: not an answer test, please use requires_file instead

content.raw: I think `data_dir_load` needs the answer testing system, in which case you should be using `requires_ds` above. When you're not using the answer testing system, I think you want to use `yt.load` directly.
content.html: I think data_dir_load needs the answer testing system, in which case you should be using requires_ds above. When you're not using the answer testing system, I think you want to use yt.load directly.

content.raw: it'll work, it's just a wrapper around `load()`. It's used by answer testing, but not the other way around.
content.html: it'll work, it's just a wrapper around load(). It's used by answer testing, but not the other way around.

content.raw: Ah you're right. For some reason I thought that it made it so the test only runs if answer testing support is turned on, but I just looked that the code and that's not right. Sorry for the noise.
content.html: Ah you're right. For some reason I thought that it made it so the test only runs if answer testing support is turned on, but I just looked that the code and that's not right. Sorry for the noise.

content.raw: The failures are caused by the fact that we store `str(ds)` as a main entry inside shelve. This one clashes with `RadAdvect/plt00000`. While the proper solution would be to fix answer testing framework, we can work around it by splitting tests into separate buckets, e.g. `local_boxlib_002` and `local_boxlib_particles_001`
content.html: The failures are caused by the fact that we store str(ds) as a main entry inside shelve. This one clashes with RadAdvect/plt00000. While the proper solution would be to fix answer testing framework, we can work around it by splitting tests into separate buckets, e.g. local_boxlib_002 and local_boxlib_particles_001

description: This (re?) implements support for Boxlib's particle file format.
